On 10/29/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
>
> > I can go=
 with "Test-Driven Development", but "Test-Driven Design" sounds
> > very d=
angerous to me.
>
> The tests don't actually drive, Cedric. I always drive.=
 The difference
> is that I write tests to try out my design decisions as I=
 go. Did you
> expect it to be any different?


That's reasonable, Joe, and=
 also how I do it, but I was commenting on this
quote:

I think, when doing=
 TDD the main benefit is not to find bugs it is to guide
your design.

... =
 which strikes me as questionable.

I would also point out that the term "T=
est-Driven Design" strongly seems to
imply that your tests drive your desig=
n.  Which is what I was objecting
against, and also why I much prefer calli=
ng it "Test-Driven Development"
(and I still think that it's something you =
should do whenever you can but
you certainly don't need to do it 100% of th=
e time to obtain well-tested
code).

-- 
C=E9dric
